episodes.natural_language:
This case, Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022, concerns a wrongful death arising from a motor vehicle accident. The client is Robyn Hester WD, a minor born on August 9, 2020. The case file notes there were no medical records related, and the PC was pronounced dead at the scene. The matter is being pursued as a wrongful death in the context of a motor vehicle accident, and the client is not currently represented by an attorney.

The intake was initiated by Robyn Hester WD’s father, Robert Sneed, who is listed as the related contact. He can be reached at (318) 272-2053 after 12:00 pm, or by email at sneed5@outlook.com. His address is 135 Austin Sneed Rd, Taylor, LA 71080. The client’s DOB is 08/09/2020, and the father’s relationship to the client is “Father.” The language of communication is English. At the time of intake, the client was not represented by an attorney for this case.

The accident occurred in Marshall County, Kentucky. The incident date is February 23, 2022, with the incident time listed as 4:00 AM and the incident date/time recorded as 2/23/2022 at 5:00:00 AM. The record indicates the accident occurred within one year from today. It is unclear who was found at fault. There were other passengers in the vehicle at the time; the passenger named is Robin Hester, who is listed as an adult. The adult passengers’ phone numbers were not obtained.

The injuries reported state that “My daughter passed away,” and the injury notes read “Deceased.” The accident involved a business/commercial vehicle and a Lyft or Uber context. Robyn Hester WD was a Passenger in Vehicle P, which was a semi that lost control and flipped over; Robyn was ejected from the vehicle and killed. The other driver is reported to have auto insurance, and the owner of the vehicle is reported to have insurance coverage.

Medical treatment is noted: the client (and/or others connected to the case) visited a doctor, hospital, chiropractor, or other medical professional as a result of the accident, and treatment was received within 30 days after the accident. The client states that the accident involved a minor and that someone else was at fault. The client was not working at the time of the accident. The death date is listed as 02/23/2022.

The Kentucky State Trooper responded to the scene; there is no report number on file, and no tickets were issued. The case is categorized as a Motor Vehicle Accident with a minor involved, and the overarching category is Wrongful Death.

Additional notes include a December 23, 2022 entry from Brandon French stating that he spoke with Robyn’s father (Robert) and obtained updated information, and that the rest of the intake packet was sent so everything needed is on file. The note clarifies that the correct date of accident or death (DOA) was 02/23/2022.

There is a message log dated December 23, 2022, at 11:28:39 AM, showing a message from 5026773361 to 3182722053. The message notes that a call had been missed and provides the office information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Ln., Louisville, KY 40222; Office phone number (502) 583-4022.

Intake records identify Brandon French as the Intake Name and Aaron Whaley as the Attorney Name. The case lists Robyn Hester WD as the Minor and lists Robert Sneed as a Related Contact. The County of Accident is Marshall, and the Time of Accident is listed as 4:00 AM. Description of the incident reiterates that Vehicle P was a passenger in a semi that lost control and flipped over, resulting in the passenger (P) being ejected and killed. The death is recorded as Deceased, and the employment status of the decedent at the time of the accident is noted as Not working. The date of death is 02/23/2022.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 concerns Robyn Hester WD, with an estate matter arising in connection with the Robyn Hester WD/MVA case. In January 2023, a sequence of emails between Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and Jeff Roberts addressed whether Jeff would be retained to set up the estate in Marshall County.

On January 13, 2023 at 3:56 PM EST, Aaron Whaley wrote to Jeff Roberts: “Jeff, hope all is well. Any more thought into this case? I am going to get the AOC 805 signed and notarized by Mr. Sneed next week. I have a service that will take the document to him and have it signed and notarized. WIll get filed as soon as I get that back. When does Marshall county have Probate docket? Thanks.” Aaron’s signature block follows, listing his contact information for Whaley Law Firm.

The following day, January 14, 2023 at 1:29 PM, Jeff Roberts replied: “Aaron Normally I would love to work this case with you. I have been going back and forth on it because I think it would be an interesting case to work up. But with the firm in Georgia getting 50% of the fee, I think I need to pass on this one. I will still help you out on local stuff if you ever need something covered or information.” The message ends with “Jeff.”

Later that same day, January 14, 2023 at 3:02 PM, Aaron Whaley responded: “I understand. No worries. Can I retain you to set up the estate in Marshall County?” Aaron’s closing signature block appears again with his Whaley Law Firm contact details.

In sum, the thread covers the intent to retain counsel to set up the Marshall County estate, Jeff Roberts’ decision to pass due to a 50% fee share arrangement with a Georgia firm, and Aaron’s ongoing plan to advance the AOC 805 filing and confirm the Marshall County probate docket schedule, including the steps to have AOC 805 signed and notarized by Mr. Sneed and filed thereafter. The message chain includes Aaron Whaley’s contact details as listed in his signature blocks.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. This note documents an email exchange in January 2023 regarding Robyn Hester’s estate matter connected to a motor vehicle accident and the related probate proceedings, which were forwarded under the subject “Robyn Hester Estate” on January 19, 2023.

The forwarded email, dated January 19, 2023 at 10:13:06 a.m. Eastern Time, originates from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and was sent to the Robyn Hester WD/MVA file at louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The chain begins with an earlier message from Aaron Whaley dated January 18, 2023 at 3:27 p.m., addressed to Bethany Willcutt, in which Aaron notes that he attached a recent case, Mason v. Stikes. He states that the case discusses the law on all the issues they have, including that a wrongful death claim is sufficient to grant jurisdiction for an ancillary estate in Kentucky; that an ancillary estate may be opened before the primary estate and that he will open a Texas Estate; and that out-of-state residents may be the administrators of said estate. The message includes Whaley’s signature block with his firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and his phone number (502-583-4022), followed by Bethany Willcutt’s contact details for Prince & Willcutt, PSC (1005 Main St, Benton, KY 42025; bethany@princewillcutt.com; phone 270-527-8612; fax 270-527-0916). The chain also contains a confidentiality statement noting the information is confidential and for the intended recipient only, with instructions to return and delete if received in error. The forwarded message appears to have been sent to the Robyn Hester WD file from Aaron and is part of the correspondence between the two law firms regarding the estate matter.

In the body of the chain, on January 18, 2023, Aaron Whaley wrote to Bethany Willcutt, attaching Mason v. Stikes and explaining the legal issues at play: that a wrongful death claim is sufficient to grant jurisdiction for an ancillary estate in Kentucky; that an ancillary estate may be opened before the primary estate, and that Aaron would open a Texas Estate; and that out-of-state residents may be the administrators of said estate.

On January 19, 2023, at 10:03 a.m., Bethany responded to Aaron, indicating that the arrangement “will work,” though she expressed concern that it may be more time-consuming than anticipated. She proposed the fee arrangement: a $2,000 nonrefundable retainer, billed against at $250 per hour, with overage billed if the retainer is exceeded. She asked if Aaron could sign the fee agreement and noted that she can send it over shortly, adding that probate court is typically Thursday afternoons.

Later that same day, at 10:12 a.m., Aaron replied: “Yes, I can sign the fee agreement. I should have the AOC form signed by Mr. Sneed later today or tomorrow.”

This correspondence, including the chain’s subject and the involved parties, was then forwarded to the Robyn Hester WD/MVA file, with the participating counsel’s signatures and contact details included in the exchange. The note preserves all stated details from the emails, including the proposed fee terms, the anticipated completion of the AOC form by Mr. Sneed, the legal points drawn from Mason v. Stikes, and the plan to open ancillary and Texas estates, as well as the confidentiality provisions present in the exchange.

On January 23, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm submitted a Notarize a Document request related to the Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022 matter. The submission indicates that the person who will be signing the document (the signer) needs to reach out to the client to arrange a signing time. Aaron reported that he spoke with Mr. Sneed, who said that sometime Wednesday would work, and provided Mr. Sneed’s phone number: 318-607-2614.

Later that same day, aENS Express Service 4 replied, stating that they were entering the order and requesting the signer’s contact information as well as the signing time and location. They noted that once those details are provided, they could finalize the order and upload the document. The message was sent by Blake Coffman, Customer Service for Express Notary Services (powered by a360inc), who included his contact details for follow-up.

The exchange includes standard confidentiality language typical of this service, indicating that the email and any attachments are intended only for the named addressees and are legally privileged or confidential, with instructions to notify the sender and delete if received in error.

The thread originates from a no-reply Weebly form submission with the subject New Form Entry: Notarize a Document. The submitted information lists Name: Aaron Whaley; Company Name: Whaley Law Firm; Email: agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com; Phone Number: 15025834022 (the 11-digit number likely corresponds to 1-502-583-4022). The submission also includes an uploaded document named 825.pdf.

Signature lines at the end of the correspondence identify Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with a contact phone number of 502-583-4022.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. The client listed for this matter is Robyn Hester WD, in the Estate of Robyn Hester.

The email thread originates from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and was sent to Bethany Willcutt and to Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022. The date on the header is January 24, 2023, at 5:33 PM Eastern Time, and the thread begins with a note that reads, “Sorry. Robert Lee Sneed III.”

In the subsequent exchange, on January 24, 2023 at 5:29 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Bethany: “Mr. Sneed has informed me that his name is actually Roert Sneed III. He hasn't signed the Oath yet or the bond. I went ahead and changed his name on those.” This followed an earlier message in the same thread, sent on January 20, 2023 at 12:17 PM, in which Whaley stated: “Here is the signed AOC. What else do you need? I am sending you a check for the retainer.” The message also included the sender’s standard closing with contact information for Whaley Law Firm.

Throughout the thread, the communications consistently identify Aaron Whaley as the sender, with the firm’s address listed as 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and the phone number 502-583-4022. There are multiple copies of Whaley’s signature and contact details included at the end of the correspondence.

In summary, the notes document a January 2023 exchange regarding the Estate of Robyn Hester, including: an early acknowledgment that the AOC had been signed and a retainer check would be sent; a correction of the client’s name from Roert Sneed III to Robert Lee Sneed III; and the observation that the client had not yet signed the Oath or the bond, with the name updated on those documents accordingly. The communications are from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Bethany Willcutt (and to Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022), with the firm’s Louisville office contact details included.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 concerns client Robyn Hester WD.

On February 8, 2023, at 2:12 PM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm emailed Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., and several others with the subject FW: Hester HEADS UP. In that message, Aaron provided the AOC 805 forms, including the fiduciary bond and an affidavit for the oath of executor. He noted that the waiver for Chabrielle is on page 4 and stated that he would reach out to the probate attorney in Marshall County to get these items filed. He added that if the waiver is signed, he would include it as an addendum.

The email thread includes subsequent replies from Chauncey Hiestand, detailing the plan and timeline. In Chauncey’s messages, he indicated that the consortium of parents’ SOL runs on February 22. He noted that Marshall County probate has court every Thursday, which means the motion needed to be on for the next Thursday in order to file within the following week (by February 22). Chauncey’s messages include the plan that Jason Ellis would work on the complaint; because of the time crunch, Aaron Whaley had the paperwork and forms to establish an ancillary estate in Marshall County with the father as administrator; Vince Johnson would work on obtaining a waiver from the mother to permit this. The plan was for a complaint to be filed and the others to intervene; he acknowledged there may already be a case filed on the wreck and asked whether they should file their own and worry about consolidation later. He also affirmed that given the SOL, they would file their own lawsuits with no motion-hour issues.

Chauncey’s earlier note, dated February 8, 2023 at 11:22 AM, outlined the same plan: Jason would draft the complaint; due to time constraints, Aaron had the paperwork and forms to establish an ancillary estate in Marshall County with the father as administrator; Vince would secure the waiver from mom; a complaint would be filed and the rest would intervene; and there was consideration of whether a separate case had already been filed on this wreck and whether consolidation would follow.

Additional context in the chain includes formal email signatures and standard notices. Chauncey, in his replies, provided his address for WINTON & HIESTAND LAW GROUP, PLLC at 905 Baxter Avenue, Louisville, KY 40204, with phone and fax numbers, and noted his updated email address crh@LouisvilleLawOffice.com. He apologized for any grammatical errors if the messages were drafted from his iPhone and included a standard confidentiality notice about the information being intended only for the recipient and the need to delete the material if received in error. The thread also contains a second version of the contact block, reiterating the same information and including the same disclaimer language.

The thread concludes with Aaron Whaley’s signature line as follows: Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022. The message references the attachments and the plan to utilize the AOC 805 fiduciary bond and executor oath forms, with the Chabrielle waiver on page 4 and the intention to file in Marshall County with the father as administrator, contingent on obtaining the waiver, and to add it as an addendum if signed.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. Re: Sneed signed docs. This matter was discussed in an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) to Kimberley Sharp (kim@princewillcutt.com), Bethany Willcutt (bethany@princewillcutt.com), and Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022, dated Wednesday, February 8, 2023 at 14:19:31 -0500. In that message, Aaron noted that the wheels keep turning and that he had been speaking with the other attorneys involved. He explained that an estate had been opened in Texas, but no administrator had been appointed. There is a pending motion to appoint a public administrator, but they will not grant it without waivers from both parents, and Mr. Sneed is not going to waive. The plan is to pursue appointment of Mr. Sneed as administrator in Texas, but Texas processes move slowly. They must also get an administrator appointed here in time to file the complaint by the February 23 deadline. Aaron stated that he could put a credit card on file for the retainer at any time and asked whether they could proceed to file and have the matter heard. He also noted that he is working on obtaining a waiver of appointment signed by Chabrielle, the mother.

The email thread continued with subsequent exchanges. On Friday, January 27, 2023 at 10:06 AM, Kimberley Sharp replied that a check could be written to Prince & Willcutt, PSC and sent to P.O. Box 466, Benton, KY 42025, and that filing could not proceed until the firm received the payment, or the client could pay by credit card over the phone. She estimated that the filing fees were $132.35 and asked to know which method the client preferred. 

Earlier, on Thursday, January 26, 2023 at 3:20 PM, Aaron Whaley asked, “No not yet. Who do I write the check to? Where do I send it?” Kimberley responded at 4:17 PM: “I do not believe so. I am going to look it over really well and double check. I am hoping to get this filed tomorrow morning after I get Bethany's signature. Have you paid the retainer yet?”

Before that, on Thursday, January 26, 2023 at 11:40 AM, Aaron Whaley, whose contact details are provided in the signature block (Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022), wrote: “Here are the signed Affidavit and Fiduciary Bond. Do you need anything else to get this filed? Thanks.” The message was followed by the standard firm signature blocks for Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, including the address and phone number.

In addition to these communications, the thread included the closing contact details for Aaron Whaley and the firm: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022. The overall sequence shows the effort to file and move forward with the administration arrangements, including expected steps, responses regarding payment and filing, and the ongoing consideration of waivers and appointment in both Texas and Kentucky.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. The client is Robyn Hester WD.

On February 9, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm wrote to Bethany Willcutt, Kimberley Sharp, and Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022 regarding “Sneed signed docs.” He stated that he really needed the matter filed and that he had to file the complaint by February 22, asking if there was anything else they needed from him.

In an earlier message dated February 8, 2023 at 2:19 PM, Whaley explained that there is an estate opened in Texas but no administrator has been appointed yet. There is a pending motion to appoint a public administrator, but waivers from both parents are required, and Mr. Sneed will not waive. The plan is to pursue appointment of Mr. Sneed as administrator in Texas; however, progress in Texas is slow. They must secure an administrator in Texas and also have one appointed here in time to file the complaint by the February 23 deadline. Whaley indicated he could call in a credit card for the retainer at any time and asked whether they could proceed to file and have a hearing. He was also working on obtaining a waiver of appointment signed by Chabrielle, the mother.

Earlier still, on January 27, 2023 at 10:06 AM, Kimberley Sharp wrote that a check could be made out to Prince & Willcutt, PSC and sent to P.O. Box 466, Benton, KY 42025, or payment could be made by credit card over the phone. She noted that filing fees were $132.35 and asked for direction on how they wanted to proceed; she would wait to file until the check was received unless they chose to pay by credit card.

On January 26, 2023 at 3:20 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, asking, “No not yet. Who do I write the check to? Where do I send it?”

Earlier that same day, at 4:17 PM, Kimberley Sharp responded that she didn’t believe there were any other requirements to file at that moment and that she intended to review everything carefully and double-check. She said she hoped to file the matter the following morning after obtaining Bethany’s signature and asked whether the retainer had been paid.

At 11:40 AM on January 26, 2023, Aaron Whaley wrote that the signed Affidavit and Fiduciary Bond were provided and asked if anything else was needed to get the matter filed, thanking the recipients.

The email thread includes the sign-off blocks from Aaron Whaley and the Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-583-4022, repeated in the communications.

In summary, the notes reflect ongoing efforts between late January and early February 2023 to prepare and file the Sneed-related documents for the Robyn Hester WD case, including securing an administrator for the Texas estate (and pursuing appointment in Kentucky by the February 23 deadline), arranging the retainer, addressing filing fees of $132.35, determining payment methods (check to Prince & Willcutt, PSC or credit card), and ensuring the signed Affidavit and Fiduciary Bond were in place, with Chabrielle (the mother) being pursued for a waiver of appointment. By February 9, 2023, there was a push to file by the February 22 deadline, with ongoing discussions about finalizing the necessary clearances and waivers.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. This note contains an email thread about the subject “Re: Sneed signed docs,” related to the Robyn Hester WD/MVA case (wrongful death/motor vehicle accident) filed on 02/23/2022.

On Friday, February 10, 2023, at 11:08:17 a.m. -0500, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Bethany Willcutt of Prince & Willcutt, PSC, with the message: “Should have it by Monday.” In a prior exchange on the same day at 10:42 a.m., Bethany outlined the situation. She stated that she would need Aaron to provide an affidavit showing that notice of the hearing was sent to the mother via certified mail and that the mother must have at least one week’s notice of the hearing. She explained that she could place the case on Thursday’s docket, but without the mother’s signature, the court would not sign off on it. This would push the matter to the following Thursday, which would be after the filing cutoff date for Aaron’s action. She emphasized the need for the mother’s signature and asked whether Aaron was confident he could obtain it. Bethany added that if the mother’s signature were obtained to allow Aaron’s client to be the administrator, the client’s written oath would be sufficient without the administrator attending in person, and that they could get everything done next Thursday.

Earlier, on February 9, 2023, at 9:01 p.m., Aaron wrote: “Should have the waiver soon.” Earlier still, at 7:27 p.m. on February 9, Bethany had written to Aaron: “Hi, Aaron, I’m going to try to get that case filed and on the docket next Thursday. If you can get me the waiver from the mother, that will make everything go much quicker/smoother. Otherwise, will father be able to come to court? If not, we can work on a Zoom link. Judge Telle is just a little particular about how he likes to do probate cases.” The thread includes confidentiality notices typical of the parties’ communications.

From the communications, Bethany’s proposed approach relied on obtaining the mother’s signature and a waiver, along with notice by certified mail, to enable the case to be filed and placed on the docket next Thursday. If the mother signed to authorize the client as administrator, the client’s written oath would suffice without attendance. The plan was to proceed with the hearing and related probate steps the following Thursday, subject to the mother’s signature, the waiver, and the judge’s preferences (Judge Telle’s particularities regarding probate proceedings). The emails also show the parties’ ongoing coordination, with contact details for the attorneys: Bethany Willcutt of Prince & Willcutt, PSC, located at 1005 Main St, Benton, KY 42025; email bethany@princewillcutt.com; phone 270-527-8612; fax 270-527-0916. Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-583-4022. The thread repeats confidentiality statements for both attorneys.

On April 13, 2023, at 1:50 PM Eastern, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email titled “Hester” to Sarena Tuttle and to Robyn Hester WD/MVA 02/23/2022 (addresses agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com and robynhesterz3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). In the body, Aaron wrote: “Sarena, see attached. This is what we need to get Robert to help answer.”

That message included the forwarded chain starting with a message from Aaron Whaley dated April 13, 2023 at 1:49 PM (the time shown as 1:49?PM). The subject was “Re: FW: Hester,” and it was addressed to Chauncey Hiestand, with Cathy Blue and Lauren Hughes CC’d (Lauren’s address shown as lah@louisvillelawoffice.com). Chauncey’s reply began with “Aaron: See attached. There are our VERY PRELIMINARY responses.” He then noted: “Please see the highlighted ones that are directed to Mr. Sneed that we have no way of answering without your assistance.” Chauncey signed as “Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq.” of WINTON & HIESTAND LAW GROUP, PLLC, with his office at 905 Baxter Avenue, Louisville, KY 40204. His contact numbers were (502) 882-3133 and (502) 882-3134 (Fax), and his email was crh@LouisvilleLawOffice.com. The message also contained an image caption and a disclaimer, including: “IF I DRAFTED FROM MY IPHONE, I APOLOGIZE FOR ANY GRAMMATICAL ERRORS,” as well as a standard confidentiality notice about the information being intended only for the recipient and instructions if received in error, plus virus-scanning and liability language.

Earlier in the forwarded chain, Cathy Blue—a Lead Paralegal at WINTON & HIESTAND LAW GROUP, PLLC—had sent an email on Thursday, April 13, 2023 at 1:07 PM to Chauncey Hiestand with Lauren Hughes CC’d. Cathy’s signature block lists WINTON & HIESTAND LAW GROUP, PLLC, 905 Baxter Avenue, Louisville, KY 40204; phone (502) 882-3133; fax (502) 882-3134; and email cjb@LouisvilleLawOffice.com. The message included the same confidentiality notice as in Chauncey’s email.

The email chain closes with the standard closing of Aaron Whaley’s signature: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the telephone number 502-583-4022. The forwarded correspondence thus documents that, as of April 13, 2023, there were “VERY PRELIMINARY” responses, and that certain items highlighted for Mr. Sneed could not be answered without further assistance from Aaron Whaley.

Separately in the same thread, on the same day at 10:44 AM (the time is indicated with a question mark in the original), Aaron Whaley forwarded the prior email chain. The forwarded portion includes a message from Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., dated Thursday, April 13, 2023 at 1:25 PM, to which Cathy Blue and Lauren Hughes were cc’d. Chauncey wrote: “See attached. There are our VERY PRELIMINARY responses. Please see the highlighted ones that are directed to Mr. Sneed that we have no way of answering without your assistance.” He signed as a partner at WINTON & HIESTAND LAW GROUP, PLLC, located at 905 Baxter Avenue, Louisville, KY 40204, with phone (502) 882-3133, fax (502) 882-3134, and email crh@LouisvilleLawOffice.com. The reason for the email this morning is to let all parties know that unfortunately this hearing will have to be canceled. Judge Moore is away at Judicial College for the next couple of weeks and she was going to hold this hearing virtually while she was away. She was informed on Friday that she would not be able to miss any of the Judicial College. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause due to the late notice. On October 9, 2023, at 14:15:40 +0000, Lacey Cavitt, Judicial Support Specialist for the Office of Circuit Judge Andrea Lee Moore (42nd Circuit, Marshall/Calloway Counties), sent a notification regarding a hearing in the Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 matter. The email was addressed to a lengthy list of recipients, including Stacie Warren, Shauna Dollins, Christine Minor, shall@waltersrichardson.com, rglass@waltersrichardson.com, Vickie Wood, Tammy Dance, "Matt Gray" (listed as "'Matt Gray'"), Jamie Deweese, Penny Wyatt, Sarena Tuttle, Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, Sara Waddell, Cathy Blue, "Kelly R. Mastin" (krmastin@kopkalaw.com), and Katie Harper. The CC field was left blank.

The email began with “Good morning.” Its purpose was to inform all parties that, unfortunately, the hearing would have to be canceled. Judge Moore is away at Judicial College for the next couple of weeks, and she had planned to hold the hearing virtually while away. She was informed on Friday that she would not be able to miss any portion of the Judicial College. The sender apologized for any inconvenience caused by the late notice and stated that they would be happy to help accommodate the parties in finding a new date for this case to be heard. The email invited recipients to contact the office with any questions.

The message was signed by Lacey Cavitt, Judicial Support Specialist, Office of Circuit Judge Andrea Lee Moore, 42nd Circuit, Marshall/Calloway Counties. The physical address listed was Judicial Building, 2nd Floor, 80 Judicial Drive, Benton, KY 42025, with a contact phone number of (270) 527-1480, Ext. 17930, and the email laceycavitt@kycourts.net.

The email also included the Kentucky Court of Justice Confidentiality Notice, which states: This message and/or attachment is intended only for the addressee and may contain information that is privileged, confidential and/or proprietary work product. If you are not the intended recipient, or an authorized employee, agent or representative of the intended recipient, you must not read, copy, retain or disseminate this message or any attachment. episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD.

The note centers on the Hester Release in the Robyn Hester WD motor vehicle accident matter, and it includes a forwarded email from Aaron Whaley to Robyn Hester WD’s Filevine project inbox dated December 2, 2024. The forwarded message carries a thread that originated with Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht of the Marshall County Sheriff’s Office in late November 2024 and concerns obtaining a release and securing counsel for the matter.

In the thread, dated November 27, 2024 at 12:43 PM, Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht replied to Aaron Whaley with the short line: “Yes, for his office.” He included his official contact information: Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht, Marshall County Sheriff’s Office, 52 Judicial Drive, Benton, KY 42025; phone 270-527-3112; fax 270-527-4759. He also attached the standard electronic confidentiality notice common to messages from the Marshall County Sheriff’s Office, which states the transmission is intended solely for the named recipient and may contain confidential, proprietary, and/or legally privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should notify the office and delete the message and any attachments.

Earlier in the same thread, at 10:58 AM on November 27, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-583-4022) had asked, “Ok that number is for Tom Blankenship?” In his response, he indicated that the message was being discussed with Tom Blankenship and sought confirmation about the contact as part of coordinating representation.

A follow-up from Sheriff Hilbrecht, dated November 27, 2024 at 11:34 AM, explained that he had reached out to Tom Blankenship. Blankenship had said he would contact Marshall County’s County Attorney Jason Darnall and get back, but he seemed willing to fill the attorney role. Hilbrecht provided Blankenship’s status and noted that if Whaley needed to contact Blankenship’s office, the number was 270-527-1444. The message again carried the Marshall County Sheriff’s Office confidentiality notice.

Earlier that day, at 4:01 PM on November 26, 2024, Aaron Whaley had written: “Hi Matt, Yes, we’re good with covering the cost of your attorney. Let me know when you have someone lined up or if there are any questions I can answer for you.” His signature block followed, listing Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022, and the same disclaimer about confidentiality.

Before that, at 4:23 PM on November 26, 2024, Matt Hilbrecht replied that after speaking with the County Attorney, he had been advised to obtain his own counsel before moving forward. He recalled Bethany Wilcutt having spoken to Aaron about concerns, and he stated his understanding (from Bethany) that Whaley would pay for him to hire his own attorney out of the proceeds, and he asked for confirmation that this arrangement was correct. His message again included his official Sheriff’s Office contact details and the confidentiality notice.

Earlier still, at 2:31 PM on November 26, 2024, Aaron Whaley wrote: “Matt just circling back on this release. Need to get it in.” He again provided his firm’s contact information and signature.

The thread ends with the continued exchange of the parties’ contact details and standard confidentiality notices, reflecting ongoing negotiations about the release (the Hester Release) and the arrangement for funding and counsel in the Robyn Hester WD MVA case. The December 2, 2024 note shows that this entire chain was forwarded to Robyn Hester WD’s project inbox as part of the case file.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022
Client: Robyn Hester WD

__Hester Estate__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [tom@bedlaw.com](mailto:tom@bedlaw.com), [RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Tue Dec 03 2024 10:48:12 GMT-05:00

Tom, I hope this email finds you well. Thank you for returning my call
yesterday. I am going to give you the Cliff Notes version of where we are
on this case and what we are doing. This case stems from a very bad
accident that happened on February 23, 2022. In that accident, Robyn Hester
was killed. Robyn was approximately 18 months old at the time. The accident
itself involved many tractor trailers and cars. I have attached the
complaint. We set up an Estate for Robyn in Marshall County with Robyn's
biological father, Robert Sneed, as the administrator. Later on, we
substituted Matt Hilbrecht as a public administrator. We have reached a
settlement against one of the tractor trailers involved. This was the
vehicle that Robyn was occupying and driven by Robyn's biological mother,
Chabrielle Hester. The only thing that we need to finalize the settlement
is the release to be signed by Matt Hilbrecht as Public Administrator. We
are still litigating against the other parties. I have attached the
complaint and the release that we need to be signed.

Let me know if you have any questions or need anything else.

-- 
Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Ln
Louisville, KY 40222
502-583-4022
episodes.natural_language:
In an email dated December 3, 2024, from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Tom Bedlaw and RobynHesterZ3101900, Whaley provides a concise update on the Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 case and the actions being taken. The email notes that the case stems from a severe accident on February 23, 2022, in which Robyn Hester was killed, and Robyn was approximately 18 months old at the time. The incident involved many tractor trailers and cars, and the complaint has been attached.

An estate was opened in Marshall County for Robyn, with Robyn’s biological father, Robert Sneed, named as administrator. Subsequently, Matt Hilbrecht was substituted as Public Administrator. A settlement has been reached with one of the tractor trailers involved—the vehicle Robyn was occupying and which was driven by Robyn’s biological mother, Chabrielle Hester. The remaining step to finalize this settlement is the release to be signed by Matt Hilbrecht in his capacity as Public Administrator. Litigation against the other parties continues. Whaley notes that the complaint and the release are attached for reference.

If there are any questions or if any additional information is needed, Whaley asks to be informed. The message closes with the sender’s contact information: Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied at 12:51 PM on February 3, 2025 that she would get the information summarized as soon as possible. Her message is accompanied by her signature block, which identifies her role and contact information, including her name, title, firm, and office details.

At 3:40 PM on February 3, 2025, Sarena followed up with a detailed update. She stated that all pleadings are up to date and referenced a filevine link. She noted that she has never been cc’d on any correspondence related to this claim and suspects there is additional discovery and/or NTTD not filed via CourtNet. She further observed that she had not received anything from Chauncey’s office directly, including expert reports, nor did it appear that any such reports had been filed.

On February 18, 2025 at 4:22 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote that he had added a Dropbox folder containing the entire file from Winton and Heistand and asked Sarena to review the contents for any depositions and expert reports.

On February 19, 2025 at 12:10 PM, Sarena sent another update titled “Re: Hester update.” She flagged several obvious items and noted that there are multiple zip files that she needed to double-check tomorrow from a computer, expressing concern that her laptop might not hold all the downloads or that she was unsure of the contents.

Sarena’s email signature on the February 19 message includes her full contact information and notes her new email address: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

This sequence captures all the core items and details exchanged: the status inquiry by Aaron as sole counsel for the Estate; the pleadings status and lack of direct communication from Chauncey Heistand’s office; the step to centralize files via Dropbox for depositions and expert reports; and the ongoing plan to verify the contents of several zip files, with the caveat about potential download capacity.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. The following narrative summarizes the email exchanges about the hearing and the Zoom link for hester/Bynum et al, labeled with the subject “hester/Bynum et al zoom link for hearing today.”

On February 21, 2025, at 01:04:37 GMT-05:00, Aaron G. Whaley of Whaley Law Firm emailed Eddie A. Jones and RobynHesterZ3101900, writing, “Eddie, I hope this email finds you well. I saw that you renewed your MSJ in this case. I am a little confused. I thought we had this settled for your $30,000 limits? Let me know. Thanks.” This indicates a renewal of the motion for summary judgment (MSJ) and raises a question about whether a settlement at the policy limits of $30,000 had been reached.

Earlier correspondence from January 28, 2025 provides context for who would be involved in the hearing. At 3:35 PM, Eddie A. Jones replied with a brief “Thank you,” followed by his professional signature, which identifies him as a Partner at BSG Paducah and provides his office address, telephone and fax numbers, email, and LinkedIn profile. The message also contained the confidentiality notice typical of attorney communications.

Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., then sent a pivotal message at 2:35 PM on January 28, 2025 to a long distribution list, including Eddie Jones, Blake Edwards, Sara Waddell, Jeri Poppe, Bobbie Harbeson, Jason Coltharp, Jake Bliss, and many others, with the subject “RE: hester/Bynum et al zoom link for hearing today.” In that message, he stated, “Aaron Whaley will proceed as counsel for the Estate. Jon Hollan obviously will continue to rep his client. Ms. Hester continues to be pro se as far as I know.” He appended his contact information and included standard attorney notices and a caution that the email originated outside the organization.

That same day, January 28, 2025, at 3:33 PM, Eddie Jones sent another message to Chauncey Hiestand and the same extended distribution list, with the subject line “RE: hester/Bynum et al zoom link for hearing today.” He wrote, “So . . . If the judge grants this pending motion, who will represent which plaintiffs?” This question concerns which counsel would represent which plaintiffs if the pending motion is granted, indicating ongoing coordination about representation in the possible post-motion landscape.

Earlier still, Chauncey Hiestand had sent a 2:09 PM message on January 28, 2025, to Blake Edwards, Sara Waddell, Jeri Poppe, Bobbie Harbeson, Jason Coltharp, Jake Bliss, Christopher Brann, Annie Brown, Charles Cassis, Justin Duncan, Jason Ellis, Anthony Finaldi, Ryan Glass, S. Madison Gray, Jenny Hines, Jonathan Hollan, Jillian House, Davis Hunter, Chad Jackson, Vincent Johnson, N. Austin Kennady, Alexander Kuebbing, Marc Lovell, Jennifer Nordstrom, Tad Pardue, Melissa Richardson, Aris Rogers, Tyler Rucker, Gregg Thornton, Daniel Wenig, and Aaron Whaley; with copies to Douglas C. Ballantine, Daniel Wenig, Christopher Schaefer, Komal Tailor, and Amelia Reesor. The subject remained the same, and he cautioned that the email originated outside the organization. In that note, he reported, “Called clerk and courts office. Stay on the line. They are running behind. No need to panic.” This reflects a real-time update about court scheduling and potential delays, advising calm while awaiting access to the hearing.

In addition to the substantive exchanges, the communications include standard attorney notices, confidentiality language, and the relevant email signatures and professional affiliations for the participants. The thread lists a broad group of recipients, reflecting extensive coordination among counsel for multiple parties in the matter, and it repeatedly references the Zoom link for the hearing today as the focal topic.

In sum, the record shows ongoing discussion about the MSJ renewal and the status of a possible settlement at the policy limits, clarifications on who will represent which plaintiffs if the pending motion is granted, and operational notes about court scheduling and delays as the hearing approached. The participants include Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), Eddie A. Jones (BSG Paducah), Chauncey Hiestand (Winton & Hiestand Law Group), and a wide distribution list of associated counsel, with Chauncey indicating that Aaron would represent the Estate, Jon Hollan would continue to represent his client, and Robyn Hester would appear pro se to the extent known. The exchange also notes that the clerk’s office was behind schedule at one point, with guidance to stay on the line and not panic.

The discussion centers on whether the decedent’s mother (referred to as “mom”) will sign a release, and what claims would remain if the Estate signs a release. The first exchange in the thread shows Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm writing to Eddie A. Jones of BSG Paducah, with Robyn Hester copied. Aaron states: “I don’t think mom will sign anything. However, what claim does she have against your client? If the Estate signs a release what claim is left that mom has? Your client didn't hit moms truck or mom.” The subject line reiterates the hearing context.

Eddie Jones replies later that same day, indicating a difficult path to settlement if the Mother will not sign a release. He writes: “There does not seem to be any path that gets this case settled if the Mother won’t sign a release. I need a settlement that releases my client from all claims related to this accident. If you think you can get Mother to sign a release I’m willing to talk.” The thread includes a standard external-email caution note and the message continues with a separate exchange that references a renewed MSJ (motion for summary judgment).

Earlier in the day, at 12:04:37 PM, Aaron Whaley sends a message to Eddie Jones and the Robyn Hester Filevine address, with the subject “Re: hester/Bynum et al zoom link for hearing today.” In this note, Aaron writes: “Eddie, I hope this email finds you well. The chain also shows earlier correspondence from January 28, 2025. In a message dated 3:35 PM, Eddie Jones wrote a brief “Thank you.” followed by his full professional signature, which lists him as a Partner at BSG Paducah, with a Paducah, KY address (410 Broadway, Paducah, KY 42001), phone number (270) 442-4369, fax (270) 442-4689, and email ejones@bsg-pad.com, along with a LinkedIn link (https://www.linkedin.com/in/eddie-jones-21bbb16/), and a confidentiality notice about attorney-client privilege.

Earlier still, Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., of Winton & Hiestand Law Group, PLC, sent a message on January 28, 2025, at 2:35 PM regarding who would represent which parties if the judge granted a pending motion. The message states: “Aaron Whaley will proceed as counsel for the Estate. Jon Hollan obviously will continue to rep his client. Ms. Hester continues to be pro se as far as I know.” The email was addressed to multiple recipients including Eddie Jones, Blake Edwards, Sara Waddell, Jeri Poppe, Bobbie Harbeson, and many others, with a cautionary note about the email originating outside the organization.

In a contemporaneous exchange on January 28, 2025, at 2:09 PM, Chauncey Hiestand asked, in a separate message,: “So . . . If the judge grants this pending motion, who will represent which plaintiffs?” This message was part of a broader thread involving numerous recipients, including Eddie Jones and Aaron Whaley, and it carried the same outside-origin caution about links or attachments.

Later, at 3:33 PM on January 28, 2025, Eddie Jones replied to Chauncey Hiestand and the same group, followed by his own signature, asking for clarification about representation in the event of a pending motion’s grant. The email chain around this date included extensive CC’d parties such as Douglas C. Ballantine, Daniel I. Wenig, Christopher E. Schaefer, Komal Tailor, and Amelia Reesor, and continued the theme of how the litigation would proceed with respect to representation among the plaintiffs.

In sum, the February 21, 2025 thread centers on settlement dynamics tied to a release from the Mother/Estate, with Aaron Whaley challenging what claims would remain if the Estate signs and noting the apparent absence of liability from the plaintiff’s side (the client did not collide with the mother or her vehicle). Eddie Jones asserts that a full release is necessary to settle, while acknowledging potential discussion if the Mother would sign. Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022

__Summary of the call with Unknown__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Mon Feb 24 2025 01:40:56 GMT-05:00

Hi

Here's the summary of the call with Unknown at 2/24 01:36 PM (UTC-05:00):

Aaron and Wilkes are strategizing on a motion for summary judgment
regarding Hester's claims, aiming to streamline the case ahead of a March
hearing.

Recap

 * Aaron is preparing requests for admissions to send to Hester, who is pro
se, but anticipates she will not respond.
 * They are working on a motion for summary judgment (msj) concerning
liability related to Hester's claims.
 * Aaron expressed the need to resolve Hester's claims to focus on Wilkes'
case.
 * Wilkes mentioned potential issues if a motion for summary judgment is
filed regarding his liability, but agreed with Aaron's approach to seek
dismissal of Hester's claims.
 * A summary judgment hearing is scheduled for the end of March, which is
critical for their timeline.
 * Both parties are aware of upcoming deadlines and trial dates that may
affect their strategy.

Tasks

 * Aaron needs to finalize and file the motion for summary judgment by the
end of March.
 * Wilkes should continue to follow up with Hester regarding her discovery
responses to clarify her claims.

Best,

On February 24, 2025, an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com summarized a call with Unknown that took place earlier that day at 1:36 PM (UTC-05:00). The case is Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022, with client Robyn Hester WD.

The summary explains that Aaron and Wilkes are strategizing on a motion for summary judgment to address Hester's claims and to streamline the case ahead of a March hearing. Aaron is preparing requests for admissions to send to Hester, who is pro se, but he anticipates she will not respond. They are working on a motion for summary judgment concerning liability related to Hester's claims. Aaron expressed the need to resolve Hester's claims so they can focus on Wilkes' case. Wilkes mentioned potential issues if a motion for summary judgment is filed regarding his liability, but he agreed with Aaron's approach to seek dismissal of Hester's claims. A summary judgment hearing is scheduled for the end of March, which is critical for their timeline. Both parties are aware of upcoming deadlines and trial dates that may affect their strategy.

Tasks include: Aaron needs to finalize and file the motion for summary judgment by the end of March, and Wilkes should continue to follow up with Hester regarding her discovery responses to clarify her claims. Best regards, Aaron Whaley.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022
Client: Robyn Hester WD

In the matter identified as Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022, concerning Robyn Hester WD, the team was seeking and confirming clarification of representation for the Hester ORDER. The exchange began with an email thread on March 6, 2025, involving Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm and Sarena M. Tuttle, the firm’s Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, with Robyn Hester WD cc’d on the communication.

Early in the day, around 1:03 PM, Sarena noted that something had been received via USPS, presumably related to the matter at hand. Later, at approximately 2:05 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Sarena outlining the content that should appear in the entry of appearance. He instructed that the filing should clarify that the firm contracted with Bethany Wilcutt to serve as local counsel for the estate and that Whaley Law Firm had been co-counsel with attorneys Winton and Heistand. He further stated that with Winton and Heistand withdrawing, Whaley Law Firm would be the sole counsel of the estate, with Bethany Wilcutt serving as local counsel.

At around 2:48 PM, Sarena prepared and sent an EOA (Entry of Appearance) with a Clarification of Representation for Aaron’s review and approval prior to filing with the Marshall County Probate Court, including her standard signature block and contact information (noting the new email address). The email was addressed to Aaron and included the Whaley Law Firm’s details and the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky office information.

Approximately an hour later, at 3:25:05 PM GMT-05:00 on the same day, Aaron responded, “Looks good, thank you,” indicating approval of the EOA with Clarification of Representation for filing.

The thread shows the chain of communications among the Whaley Law Firm team regarding the representation status for the estate in this case. The discussion confirms that the estate’s counsel arrangement had shifted from a multi-counsel arrangement (with Winton and Heistand) to a configuration where The Whaley Law Firm is the sole counsel, with Bethany Wilcutt serving as local counsel, and that the EOA with Clarification of Representation was prepared for filing with Marshall County Probate Court. The cc line indicates Robyn Hester WD was included in the correspondence.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. This matter concerns the Estate of R.H. v Toussaint et al, specifically a deposition scheduling issue for Mr. Sean Wilkes and a corporate representative of All In Trucking Corp, in connection with the case in which Robyn Hester WD is the client.

On Friday, March 21, 2025, at 1:27:07 PM (EDT), Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email regarding deposition scheduling for Mr. Sean Wilkes and a corporate representative of All In Trucking. The message, addressed to counsel including Mrs. Poppe and Mr. Brown of Donk Brown Law, with a broad CC list of recipients from multiple firms, carried the subject: Estate of R.H. v Toussaint et al - Deposition Scheduling - Mr. Sean Wilkes & All In Trucking Corp Rep. In the body, Tuttle explained that approximately ten days prior the office had requested dates on which Mr. Wilkes and a corporate representative of All In Trucking would be available for depositions, but to date no response had been received. She requested that the recipients provide available dates as soon as possible to avoid delays in the claim and offered to discuss any questions directly. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address listed as 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the following contact details: D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is a new email address.

This communication followed an earlier message from Tuttle on Tuesday, March 11, 2025, at approximately 1:10 PM, in which she stated that the office would like to begin scheduling the deposition of Mr. Sean Wilkes and a corporate representative for All In Trucking. She requested dates on which Mr. Wilkes and/or a corporate representative could be available, and added that if anyone did not intend to attend the deposition, they should advise so the office would not await their response. The March 11 message also included Tuttle’s signature block with the same contact information and the note to use the new email address.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD.

In the Robyn Hester WD matter, the latest update came on March 11, 2025, from Sarena M. Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm. In her message to Aaron Whaley (with RobynHesterZ3101900@ louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com copied), she noted that she had sent out the initial request for deposition dates and had drafted a Scheduling Chart to keep track of responses. She planned to save the chart to a file and pin it to the top for easy reference and would update it as responses came in. Her signature also indicates her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with her contact information for the firm.

Earlier correspondence establishes the ongoing status and planning. On February 3, 2025 at approximately 10:51 AM, Aaron Whaley stated that he was now sole counsel for the Estate and that they needed to determine the overall status: the trial date with deadlines, who had been deposed, what expert reports had been obtained from Chauncey Heistand, and which parties were out or remaining in the case. Later that same day, at about 12:51 PM, Sarena replied that she would get the status summarized as soon as possible. She added that all pleadings were up to date, providing a quick glance based on the pleadings in the file (with a FileVine link). She also noted that she had never been cc’d on any correspondence related to this claim and suspected there was additional discovery and/or NTTD that had not been filed via CourtNet. She further stated she had not received anything directly from Chauncey’s office, including expert reports, nor did it appear those reports had been filed. A follow-up message from Sarena later on February 3 reiterated that she would summarize the status, and she again confirmed the pleadings were up to date and referenced the FileVine link, while maintaining that she had not received materials from Chauncey Heistand.

On February 18, 2025 at approximately 4:22 PM, Aaron Whaley sent a message noting that he had added a Dropbox folder containing the entire file from Winton and Heistand and asked Sarena to review it for any depositions and expert reports.

On February 19, 2025, at about 12:11 PM, Sarena responded with: “Here are the obvious items. There are several Zip Files that I need to double check tomorrow from a computer. Not sure my laptop can hold all the downloads, not knowing what is in them.” A short time later, at approximately 12:40 PM, Aaron replied: “Ok, we need to get depositions of the driver of the All in Trucking semi. Sean Wilkes and get a 30(b)(6) deposition of All in Trucking.”

These exchanges collectively reflect ongoing deposition planning, document collection, and status updates as the case moves toward scheduling and discovery milestones.

Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD.

In the Estate of RH, case number 23-CI-00074, counsel correspondence in March 2025 shows ongoing settlement negotiations regarding the related motor-vehicle matter. The forward chain begins with an email thread among Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, Blake V. Edwards, Esq., and others about a proposed settlement in the Estate of RH, with the subject Estate of RH (23-CI-00074).

On March 17, 2025, Blake V. Edwards, Esq., who represents Orozco, Alexsul, and Mr. Mikhail, wrote to Aaron Whaley. He explained that they had filed a Motion for Summary Judgment the previous week. Edwards noted that Mr. Mikhail was operating a semi and was able to come to a successful stop without striking anybody or anything, and he speculated that Mr. Hiestand had the case before Aaron. Edwards stated that his clients did not have anything to do with causing the accident with Aaron’s client and asked whether he could send an Agreed Order of Partial Dismissal on those claims, inviting any questions. Edwards provided his contact information: Blake V. Edwards, Esq., Partner, 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1703; Direct Fax: 502.779.9348. The message also included the standard confidentiality notice.

On March 18, 2025, at 2:33 PM, Aaron Whaley responded to Blake. Aaron thanked Blake for reaching out and said he was working on his reply to the various MSJs and asked whether Blake would be open to a nominal settlement. He referenced a global offer from all defendants at mediation and noted uncertainty about each party’s contribution; he mentioned that Marc Lovell had taken a similar stance and that they had reached a nominal settlement to resolve him out of the litigation.

Earlier that same day, at 3:51 PM, Blake replied with a money question: “How much are you thinking so I know when I report back to the adjuster? $2,500?” He again provided his firm’s contact details: Blake V. Edwards, Esq., Partner, 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1703; Direct Fax: 502.779.9348, together with the confidentiality notice.

Also on March 18, 2025, at 8:09 PM, Aaron sent another message to Blake, stating, “I was thinking $5,000. Not far off considering.” He again identified his law firm and address: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022, and reaffirmed the ongoing discussion about a settlement amount.

On March 19, 2025, at 10:15 AM, Blake asked Aaron, “Is that a firm demand? If so, I will discuss with my adjuster.” Aaron’s reply at 12:08 PM was a brief confirmation: “yes.”

Later on March 19, 2025, at 1:23 PM, Blake forwarded a reply stating, “My clients have accepted your client’s demand of $5k, which is inclusive of all liens except PIP. Please send me your W-9 and instructions on how the settlement check should be made payable. In the meantime, I will prepare the settlement documents.” This message closed with Blake’s signature and confidentiality notice, along with the contact details for the SBM Kentucky office: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1703; Direct Fax: 502.779.9348.

The forwarded thread itself began with Aaron Whaley’s initial reply on March 19, 2025 at 12:08 PM, simply replying “yes” to Blake’s question about whether the amount discussed was a firm demand. The earlier message from Aaron on March 18, 2025 at 2:33 PM had indicated a willingness to consider a nominal settlement, as described above.

The exchange repeated several times in the forwarded content shows the same parties (Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm; Blake V. Edwards, Esq.; with copies to Daniel I. Wenig and Amelia Reesor) and the same contact details and confidentiality language present in the signatures. The key outcome reflected in the latest forward is that Blake’s clients accepted the $5,000 settlement demand, inclusive of all liens except PIP, and Blake requested a W-9 and instructions for how the settlement check should be payable, with an affirmation that he would prepare the settlement documents.

Next steps implied by the thread include providing the W-9 to Blake, detailing how the settlement check should be made payable, and the preparation of the settlement documents for the Estate of RH (23-CI-00074). The involved attorney contact details are as follows: Blake V. Edwards, Esq., Partner, SBM Kentucky (address provided in the signature: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1703; Direct Fax: 502.779.9348). For Whaley Law Firm, the contact is Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022. The communications include standard confidentiality notices.

The matter involves preparing a probate filing for the Marshall County Probate Court to confirm that the firm represents the estate and will pay the public administrator and his attorney at the end of the case.

On March 26, 2025, a sequence of email exchanges occurred between Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm and Sarena M. Tuttle, the firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, regarding the probate filing. The earliest message in the thread, sent at approximately 9:47 AM, stated: “I need to file something with the Probate Court in Marshall county that confirms that I will be paying. I have attached what Heistand is filing and I need to file something similar. Just to say that I am representing the Estate and will pay the public administrator and his attorney at the end of the case.” Aaron signed the message as “Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.”

Later that morning, at about 10:20 AM, Sarena asked, “How does this look?” and provided her contact details, including her note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.” Her signature block listed her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971), office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and email (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com).

Around 10:37 AM, Aaron replied, “Looks good, thank you.” At approximately 10:58 AM, Sarena responded, “Awesome. Will get this file now,” again with her standard signature block. The CC for the exchange included Robyn Hester via RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD.

On May 1, 2025, at 12:14:22 PM Eastern Time, an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm was sent to Linda Jones and to RobynHesterZ3101900, with the subject line indicating a forwarding of “FW: Sneed.” In that message, Whaley asked Linda to forward a copy of her report on Robyn Hester, noting that he had the cover letter but could not locate the report and thanked her in advance.

This email included a forwarded message from Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., dated Wednesday, June 19, 2024, at 1:07 PM (the exact seconds not specified). The forwarded message, addressed to Linda Jones, Aaron Whaley, and Jon Drake with the subject “FW: Sneed,” stated: “Linda, here is what we were able to get from Mr. Sneed. This is all we can get.” The message was signed by Chauncey R. Hiestand, Esq., of Winton & Hiestand Law Group, PLLC, located at 905 Baxter Avenue, Louisville, KY 40204, with phone and fax numbers 502-882-3133 and 502-882-3134, and the email crh@LouisvilleLawOffice.com. The body also included notice that the message contained images (as indicated by references to image placeholders) and an encouragement that if he drafted from his iPhone, any grammatical errors should be forgiven. It further contained a standard confidentiality and virus disclaimer: the information is intended only for the addressee and may be confidential or privileged; review, retransmission, dissemination, or action in reliance upon it by others is prohibited; if received in error, the recipient should contact the sender and delete the material; the email and any attachments should be scanned for viruses; no liability is accepted for any loss or damage from a virus or transmission defects.

The forwarded portion from Aaron Whaley to Chauncey Hiestand, dated June 19, 2024, at 12:41 PM, with the subject “Sneed,” stated: “I got him on the phone. Limited information but here is what I could get in the conversation.” The information Whaley reported from the conversation included:

- Graduated Gibsland Coleman High School in 2001
- Gibsland, Louisiana
- Career Technical College CDL training in 2014, in Shreveport, LA
- Coast to Coast Trucking in 2023 for 8 months
- Excel Trucking in 2023 for 1 month
- Fadiburn Miniton industrial, 9 years of work, earning $18 per hour

The message concluded with the sender’s contact information:

Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
Phone: 502-583-4022

The communication cycle included the repetition of Aaron Whaley’s contact details in a second block, and again the same street address and phone number.

In summary, the chain of correspondence shows a request on May 1, 2025, for Robyn Hester’s report, a June 19, 2024, forward from Chauncey Hiestand indicating limited information obtained from Mr. Sneed, and from Aaron Whaley a detailed verbal background obtained from a phone conversation dated June 19, 2024, describing Mr. Sneed’s education and trucking employment history.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Robyn Hester WD motor vehicle accident case (Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022), the client is Robyn Hester WD. On May 5, 2025, a thread of emails began concerning the response to a defense motion for summary judgment (MSJ). The first message in the thread was sent at 12:58 PM from Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at the same firm, with Robyn Hester’s file cc’d. In that email, Aaron stated that he had attached his rough response to the defendants’ MSJ, along with the original MSJ and an expert report from Linda Jones. He instructed that the response to MSJ be placed in the proper format for filing and asked Sarena to prepare a motion for late expert disclosure and an expert disclosure, noting that Linda Jones is the only expert. He requested confirmation of receipt and signed off with his contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Later that day, at 2:18 PM, Sarena replied, confirming “Got it,” and again providing her contact details and noting the new email address. Her signature listed her role as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address and phone numbers, and the line to the new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

In a subsequent message around 2:49 PM, Sarena sent another note to Aaron with the subject “Here is the Resp to DC MSJ - Working on Motion for Late Expert.” In that email, she again identified herself as Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and provided the firm’s contact details and the note to the new email address. This message appears to be part of the ongoing process to prepare and file the response to the MSJ and related motions.

At 3:33 PM on the same day, the original sender’s thread continued with Sarena sending a further update titled “Here is the Motion for Leave to File Expert Disclosures, the Proposed Order & the Expert Disclosures.” In this communication, she noted that the only Expert Disclosure Template she currently had is for a Medical Expert, and she attached the Word version so Aaron could file in the A & B sections. She emphasized the importance of including all subjects and subject matters the expert may discuss and not missing anything. Her contact details were included again, with the reminder to use the new email address.

Throughout the thread, the communications consistently reference Linda Jones as the sole expert, and the team discusses the preparation of a motion for late expert disclosure and an expert disclosure, the response to the MSJ, and the required formats and disclosures for filing. The communications also repeatedly provide the participants’ names, firm affiliations, addresses, and contact information, including the new email address for Sarena Tuttle.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 concerns the client Robyn Hester WD and centers on a response to a motion for summary judgment (MSJ) and the related expert disclosures. In early May 2025, the Whaley Law Firm team coordinated the preparation and filing of the MSJ response and the accompanying expert disclosure, with instructions to include Linda Jones’s expert report and to remove a cover-page letter to Chauncy before filing.

On May 5, 2025, at approximately 12:58 PM, Aaron Whaley emailed that he had attached his rough response to the defendants’ motion for summary judgment. He stated that he had included the original motion as well as an expert report from Linda Jones and asked that the response to MSJ be put in the proper filing format. He also requested the preparation of a motion for late expert disclosure and an expert disclosure, noting that the only expert is Linda Jones, and asked for confirmation of receipt of the email. His signature block identifies him as Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone numbers 502-583-4022 and the email agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com.

At 2:18 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied simply with “Got it,” signing with her title, firm, and contact details: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting the new email address.

Later that same afternoon, at approximately 2:49 PM, Sarena wrote a brief follow-up: “Here is the Resp to DC MSJ - Working on Motion for Late Expert,” again providing her title and contact information as above.

Around 3:33 PM, Sarena sent the message: “Here is the Motion for Leave to File Expert Disclosures, the Proposed Order & the Expert Disclosures.” She noted that the only Expert Disclosure Template available was for a Medical Expert, so she attached the Word version for filing in the A and B sections. She stressed the importance of including all subjects and subject matters the expert may discuss and do not want to miss anything. Her signature block again lists her role and contact information, including the firm address and the note about the new email address.

On Tuesday, May 6, 2025, at 8:55 AM, Aaron Whaley replied: “Looks good. Here is the revised expert disclosure. The response to summary judgment also looks good. Let’s get it filed. File the report from Linda Jones with the disclosure. Take off the cover page letter to Chauncy first.” He cc’d RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com and affirmed that the response to MSJ and the revised expert disclosure were ready for filing. He reiterated the instruction to file Linda Jones’s report with the disclosure and to remove the cover-page letter to Chauncy prior to filing.

The exchange reflects the team’s plan to file the MSJ response along with Linda Jones’s expert report, to prepare a motion for late expert disclosure and an expert disclosure (the sole expert being Linda Jones), and to ensure all relevant subject matters would be disclosed. The communications include the full names, roles, firm contact details, and email addresses for all participants, as well as the procedural notes to remove the cover page letter before filing.

This narrative summarizes a May 9, 2025 eFiling processing notice related to the case file associated with the motor vehicle accident matter for Robyn Hester WD, and its connection to the Sneed v. Tossaint/Mayiquel et al litigation in Marshall Circuit Court.

On May 9, 2025 at 1:33 PM Central Time (2:33 PM Eastern), the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system returned the envelope number 10569810 for envelope submission in case 23-CI-00074, captioned SNEED, ROBERT ET AL VS. TOSSAINT, MAYIQUEL ET AL. The submission was denied. The denial notice, issued under the NCP – RETURNED (for eFiler) MARSHALL 23-CI-00074, indicated that the case has been consolidated with 23-CI-73 and instructed the filer to refile in the correct case. The notice advised that the items must be resolved and resubmitted to the Circuit Clerk by May 13, 2025 at 11:59 PM Central / 2:33 PM Eastern. If there is a right to a monetary refund, the filer should contact the Marshall Circuit Court Clerk. The eFiler listed for this submission was Aaron G. Whaley, attorney for the Plaintiff.

Court information included in the notice shows the filing was for the MARSHALL (CIRCUIT) Court, in the case caption SNEED, ROBERT ET AL VS. episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes the email communications in the matter Jerom e Hedinger v. 432 Atwood, LLC, et al., Jefferson County case 24-CI-006943, as they relate to discovery in the Robyn Hester WD motor vehicle accident matter (Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022) for the client Robyn Hester WD. The principal participants were W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, Louisville, KY, and Paige E. Hornback, Associate at Dinsmore & Shohl LLP, Louisville, KY. The email chain began on February 17, 2025 and continued through May 1, 2025, with the standard attorney‑client privilege notices appearing in each message. The email header for this note shows the following cross‑references: From Bryce Koon to Paige Hornback, with CCs to Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address, Sarena Tuttle, David Klapheke, Elizabeth Harbolt, and Linda Bandy.

On February 17, 2025, Bryce Koon sent an email attaching Plaintiff’s Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC, along with the associated notice filed that day, and included a Word copy for the recipients’ convenience. The email was addressed to David Klapheke and Paige Hornback and was cc’d to Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address and Sarena Tuttle. The message included a standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer stating that the electronic transmission may constitute privileged communications and, if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not use or forward the information.

Paige Hornback replied later on February 17, 2025 at 12:59 PM: “Bryce, Received. Thanks for forwarding.” Bryce’s initial message to David Klapheke and Paige Hornback had been sent at 12:56 PM, with the same CCs noted, and contained the text: “Attached please find Plaintiff's Discovery Requests to Defendant 432 Atwood, LLC along with the associated notice filed today. Included is a word copy for your convenience. If you have any questions in this regard, please let me know.” This earlier message included the same privilege disclaimer typical of attorney communications.

The chain continued on March 19, 2025. At 12:16 PM, Paige Hornback wrote: “Hi Bryce, I hope you’re well. We are showing that our discovery responses are due to you today, and we are working on finalizing our responses. However, we need some additional information and documents to finalize and serve. Could we have an additional 30 days to respond? This would update our deadline to Friday, April 18, 2025. Please let us know if this is agreeable – thanks!” Bryce Koon then replied at 12:28 PM: “Paige, Not a worry at all. Thank you for getting back to me - April 18th will be fine.” The messages again included the standard privilege disclosure.

Later on March 19, 2025, at 11:41 AM (in the same thread), Bryce had previously circulated the discovery material and related notices, with the same attorney‑client disclaimer included at the end of the message chain.

On April 23, 2025, at approximately 11:10 AM, Bryce Koon wrote: “Good morning Paige, Just circling back on these responses. Any updated appreciated.” This message also carried the privilege disclaimer customary to the correspondence.

Finally, on May 1, 2025, at 4:27:26 PM, Bryce Koon sent another follow‑up to the recipients: “Good afternoon counsel, Following up on these again.” The May 1 note, like the earlier messages, was sent from The Whaley Law Firm and included the same standard privilege language.

Throughout the correspondence, the CC list remained consistent, including Jerome Hedinger DB 10/24/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address, Sarena Tuttle, David Klapheke, Elizabeth Harbolt, and Linda Bandy. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information (The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: 502-365-5043; Fax: 502-237-3207) and Paige Hornback’s Dinsmore & Shohl contact block (101 South Fifth Street, Suite 2500, Louisville, KY 40202; T 502-540-2594; F 502-585-2207; E Paige.Hornback@dinsmore.com) appear in the signature blocks, along with the invitation not to forward privileged information if received in error. The messages also include standard notices that the communication may contain attorney‑client privileged material and should be treated accordingly.
