Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022
Client: Robyn Hester WD

In June 2025, the matter for Robyn Hester WD, associated with the Robyn-Hester-WD motor vehicle accident case, involved a settlement discussion related to the Bynum & Hester Estate. On Monday, June 23, 2025 at 09:09:47 AM (GMT-05:00), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, forwarded an email thread to RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. Whaley’s contact details were listed as Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022.

The forwarded chain contains a message from James R. (Jason) Coltharp, Jr., of Whitlow Law, addressed to Aaron G. Whaley and Jonathan Hollan (jhollan@kylawoffice.com). Dated Monday, June 23, 2025, at about 9:03 AM, the subject line read “Bynum & Hester Estate settlement.” In the body, Jason stated that attached is a proposed release for Michael Bynum and the Robin Hester Estate’s settlement with Ion Fetcu and OEG Express. He asked to be informed if any changes were required. He noted that he had a W-9 from Jon but not from Aaron. He stated that once he had assent to the release from both parties and a W-9 from Aaron, he would request Progressive to issue the payments.

Jason Coltharp signed as James R. (Jason) Coltharp, Jr., Member, and provided his contact information: jcoltharp@whitlow-law.com; Office phone 270-443-4516; Cell 270-519-7431. His mailing address was 300 Broadway, Post Office Box 995, Paducah, Kentucky 42002-0995, and his fax number was 270-443-4571. The firm’s website is www.whitlow-law.com.

The message included an image attachment (described as: image001.png). The email contained a standard confidentiality notice stating that the message is intended only for the addressee and may contain privileged, confidential, and/or attorney work product information. It warned that reading, copying, retaining, or disseminating the message or attachments is inappropriate if you are not the intended recipient, and instructed the unintended recipient to contact the sender and delete all copies. It also stated that neither transmission nor any error in transmission constitutes a waiver of legal privilege.

Additionally, the email carried IRS Circular 230 notice, clarifying that any U.S. tax advice contained is not intended or written to be used for avoiding penalties under the Internal Revenue Code or for promoting or recommending any transaction addressed in the communication.

In summary, the current note documents an ongoing effort to finalize the Bynum & Hester Estate settlement with Ion Fetcu and OEG Express, contingent on obtaining W-9 forms from both Jon and Aaron and obtaining assent to the proposed release, after which Progressive would be requested to issue the settlements.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022 concerns the client Robyn Hester WD and centers on the Hester Release. On October 13, 2025 at 2:24:13 a.m./p.m. (Eastern Time), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Blake V. Edwards of SBMKY Law regarding the release, with RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, Daniel I. Wenig, and Amelia Reesor copied on the email. The subject line was “Re: Hester Release,” and the note said to see the attached documents.

In a follow-up dated October 13, 2025 at about 1:08 p.m., Blake V. Edwards replied to Aaron, indicating that they should follow up again before filing their Motion this week. Edwards’ address and contact details were included in his signature, and the message contained the confidentially notice typical of firm correspondence.

The email thread shows a ongoing negotiation about whether to provide the executed settlement agreement or to file a Motion to Enforce. A prior exchange from October 3, 2025 (Blake’s message to Aaron, with RobynHesterZ3... copied and Daniel Wenig and Amelia Reesor CC’d) asked: “Aaron, Are you going to provide the executed settlement agreement or do we need to file the Motion to Enforce?”

Earlier, on September 17, 2025, Blake followed up again on the status of the executed Release, asking for an update.

The discussion traces back to September 2, 2025, when Aaron Whaley responded to Blake and RobynHesterZ3..., with Daniel Wenig and Amelia Reesor CC’d. In his message, Aaron stated that what another party does or has agreed to has no persuasive effect for him on the issue at hand; his aim was to protect his client and ensure the language complies with Kentucky law rather than merely checking a box. He explained that other parties’ actions may have persuasive effect on the Judge, and reminded Blake that if they could not reach an agreement, Blake would need to file a Motion to Enforce. He asked Blake to send a complete copy of the release with the new proposed language so that Aaron could determine whether the Sheriff would sign it; if not, Blake would need to file the motion. He quoted the language Blake had proposed at that time:

“Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht signs this Release only in his capacity as an administrator of the Estate of R.H. pursuant to KRS 396.185. He is binding the estate, and neither he, nor the Marshall County Sheriff’s Department, is personally bound or liable for the representations herein.”

Aaron explained that his previous language was drafted to comply with KRS 396.185, which concerns the liability of a personal representative, and that omitting “fiduciary” from the proposed language ignored the statute’s direct language. He noted that the statute states that a personal representative is individually liable for obligations arising from ownership or control of the estate or for torts committed in the course of administering the estate only if the personal representative is personally at fault. Therefore, he argued that language stating that the personal representative is not “personally bound or liable for the representations herein” could directly contradict the statute. He stated that he had provided his rationale for why the language was not acceptable and asked why the language he proposed was not acceptable under Kentucky law. He proposed the following alternative language:

“Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht signs this Release in his fiduciary capacity as the administrator of the Estate of R.H. pursuant to KRS § 396.185 and not in his personal capacity or official capacity with the Marshall County Sheriff.”

He invited Blake to share his thoughts and suggested a phone conversation if needed.

In his later August 27, 2025 message, Aaron reiterated a revision for consideration, proposing to revise to say:

“Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht signs this Release only in his capacity as an administrator of the Estate of R.H. pursuant to KRS 396.185. He is binding the estate, and neither he, nor the Marshall County Sheriff’s Department, is personally bound or liable for the representations herein.”

Aaron added that he did not think the language was necessary or that a judge would compel the Sheriff to sign Blake’s preferred language. He observed that the original language he had requested—which Blake had objected to—had since been adopted by another party, and he noted that this had resulted in at least six parties having no problems with it (though the sentence ends there in the correspondence).

In sum, the October 13, 2025 emails reflect an ongoing effort to determine whether to file a Motion to Enforce or obtain the executed settlement agreement, and they document a dispute over the precise language governing Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht’s signing of the Release in relation to KRS 396.185, including the tension between a fiduciary-capacity formulation versus language that might be read as personally binding.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Robyn-Hester-WD-MVA-02-23-2022. Client: Robyn Hester WD. Re: Hester Release.

On November 4, 2025 at 10:57:43 AM (GMT-05:00), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Blake V. Edwards at SBMKY Law, with Robyn Hester’s file color-coded in the cc line to RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, Daniel I. Wenig, and Amelia Reesor. The subject was Re: Hester Release. In that message, Aaron stated, “Blake, I did get the check. You can go ahead and file that.”

Earlier, on Friday, October 31, 2025 at 2:14 PM (the timestamp shows a question mark after the time), Blake Edwards had written to Aaron inquiring about the status of the delivery of the settlement check to determine whether he could proceed with filing the AOD. Blake explained that USPS attempted to deliver the check to Aaron’s office on October 17, but no one was available to receive it. USPS’s website indicated that a notice had been left at the office requesting a reschedule of delivery, which had not yet been done. Blake provided the USPS tracking link: https://tools.usps.com/go/TrackConfirmAction?qtc_tLabels1=9489017898203032574827. He asked, “Have you received the check? Can we file the AOD?” The email carried Blake’s signature as “Blake V. Edwards, Esq.—Partner,” with his office address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, and direct contact numbers. The message also included confidentiality language stating that the communication and attachments were intended for the recipient and protected by attorney-client/work product privileges, with instructions to notify the sender if received in error and to destroy the communication.

In the chain, Aaron had previously replied on October 13, 2025 at 2:24 PM with “See attached,” to Blake’s prior message, and the thread continued with further exchanges.

On Monday, October 13, 2025 at 1:08 PM, Blake wrote to Aaron: “Aaron Follow up again before we go forward with filing our Motion this week.” The message included Blake’s standard signature block.

On Friday, October 3, 2025 at 1:52 PM, Blake had written to Aaron and RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with Robyn’s email address included, and cc’d Daniel I. Wenig and Amelia Reesor. The subject was RE: Hester Release. Blake asked, “Aaron, Are you going to provide the executed settlement agreement or do we need to file the Motion to Enforce?” The note again contained Blake’s contact information and the confidentiality notice.

Earlier, on Wednesday, September 17, 2025 at 3:10 PM, Blake sent another message to Aaron and RobynHesterZ3101900@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with Daniel I. Wenig and Amelia Reesor cc’d, titled RE: Hester Release. Blake wrote, “Aaron Following up on the status of the executed Release. Thanks.” The message included Blake’s standard signature and confidentiality notice.

On Tuesday, September 2, 2025 at 2:43 PM, Aaron replied to Blake, Robyn Hester, Daniel Wenig, and Amelia Reesor. His reply began with a substantive note: “What another party does or has agreed to has no persuasive effect for me on this issue. I am simply trying to protect my client and have this language make sense and comply with Kentucky law rather than just checking a box and moving on.” He added that what other parties do would have persuasive effect on the Judge, and that in their last conversation Blake had said he would file a motion to enforce the settlement if an agreement could not be reached. Aaron requested a complete copy of the release with Blake’s new proposed language and stated he would see if the Sheriff would sign it; if not, Blake would need to file the motion. Aaron then quoted the language Blake had proposed at that time:

“Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht signs this Release only in his capacity as an administrator of the Estate of R.H. pursuant to KRS 396.185. He is binding the estate, and neither he, nor the Marshall County Sheriff’s Department, is personally bound or liable for the representations herein.”

Aaron explained that his last proposed language had been drafted to comply with KRS 396.185, “Liability of personal representative,” while also considering Blake’s proposed language. He argued that omitting “fiduciary” from the proposed language would ignore the statute’s language, which states that “a personal representative is individually liable for obligations arising from ownership or control of the estate or for torts committed in the course of the administration of the estate only if he is personally at fault.” He stressed that they could not include language contradicting the statute by stating that the personal representative is NOT “personally bound or liable for the representations herein.” Aaron stated he had provided his rationale for why the language was not acceptable and asked why Blake’s proposed language was not acceptable under Kentucky law. He closed by restating his proposed language:

“Sheriff Matt Hilbrecht signs this Release in his fiduciary capacity as the administrator of the Estate of R.H. pursuant to KRS § 396.185 and not in his personal capacity or official capa[city].” (The final word in the note truncates at “capa.”)

In sum, the correspondence trail shows ongoing discussions through September, with a focus on obtaining an executed Release that complies with Kentucky law (KRS 396.185), determining whether an AOD (Order of Abatement of Debt) could be filed, and coordinating whether to file a Motion to Enforce the settlement agreement if the parties could not reach agreement on the release language. The records reflect multiple rounds of proposed language for the Release, dialogue about the Sheriff’s personal versus fiduciary capacity, and requests to confirm delivery and receipt of the settlement check so that related filings could proceed.

Finally, in the November 4, 2025 email from Aaron to Blake, Aaron confirmed receipt of the check and authorized Blake to proceed with filing that item.
